subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Over the past decades, Split Topicalization (ST) has attracted an increasing amount of attention. And sometimes, this construction, which used to be considered only a marginal phenomenon, even figured in important theoretical debates, as for instance whether German is configurational (cf. Fanselow 1987; Webelhuth 1990) or whether extraction should be assigned a derivational or representational analysis (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1989a; Brody 1995).

subsection.heading: 1.1 Some general remarks about Topicalization
subsection.p: Since ST forms a special kind of Topicalization (T), some general remarks about (unsplit) Topicalization are in order. The term ‘Topicalization’ was introduced by Ross (1986, originally a 1967 dissertation) as a name for a transformation that fronts a non-wh-constituent to the left-periphery of the clause. Nowadays, the minimal assumption is that the topicalized constituent is located somewhere in the IP/CP-domain and is coindexed with an empty category inside the clause: 1

(1)
a. [[NP Beans]i [IP I don't like [e]i]]. (Ross 1986: (5.68))
b. [[AP Proud of him]i [IP I've never been [e]i]]. (Ross 1986: (5.69))

T creates an unbounded A-bar-dependency relation with island and connectivity effects. The term ‘Topicalization’ refers to the intuitive information-structural function of this preposing transformation, which is to mark the fronted constituent as a sentence topic, i.e., as the entity the sentence is about. In this most frequent use of T, the primary accent is on a constituent within the clause, while the topicalized constituent bears a somewhat weaker accent. 2
(2) BEANS, I don't LIKE.

ST – the topic of this chapter – forms a special kind of T. The languages in which ST is attested form a subset of the languages that have T. The phenomenon of ST has been investigated most extensively with respect to Split Noun Phrase Topicalization and Split Verb Phrase Topicalization (SVPT) in German.

subsection.heading: 1.2 Different categorial types of Split Topicalization
subsection.p: ST gives rise to a split-constituent dependency of the following kind: a constituent's core is extracted to the pre-field while leaving its non-core behind in the middle-field of the clause: 3
The most frequent categorial type of ST in German is Split Noun Phrase Topicalization (SNPT). The German example in (4) forms a case in point:

(4)
[CP [TOP
Bohnen] [C′
magi
er nur [REM
grüne ___ ]ti]].
beans likes he only green
‘As for beans, he likes only green ones.’

In (4), not the entire direct object has been topicalized, as in (1a), but only its core: the adjectival modifier of the topicalized noun has been stranded within the clause. The topicalized part of a ST will be referred to as top and the stranded part as rem. 4 top and the gap in rem always corefer and must therefore be co-indexed.

By what syntactic criterion does an instance of T become classified as an instance of ST? For example in (5), part of the embedded clause has been topicalized. Does this instance of subextraction (see chapter 66) count as an instance of ST?

(5)
[CP [Grüne Bohnen]i [C′
glaube ich, [CP
dass er gerne mag [e]i]]].
green beans believe I that he very much likes
‘Green beans, I think he likes very much.’

In order to determine the class of STs cross-categorially, the notion of extended projection (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1998a and the references therein) comes into play. Without going into the technical details of this notion, it will be assumed that an extended projection consists of the lexical projection plus its functional extensions. The categorial features of all the projection nodes in an extended projection have to be identical. So, while an incomplete nominal extended projection has been topicalized in (4), in the T in (5) it is a full extended nominal projection (NP) that is extracted out of CP in (5), and not an incomplete CP. So, the subextraction in (5) is not an instance of ST. One could say that in ST, a single (extended) projection is scattered over different positions in the clause. 5

Besides the ST of arguments, which mainly comes about by SNPT, predicates can also undergo ST. The main categorial type of split predicate T is Split Verb Phrase Topicalization (SVPT) in German and Dutch. (6) provides a clear example of this second type of ST, which matches the scheme in (3):

(6)
[CP [Gegessen] [C′
hat [IP
er [VP
nur grüne Bohnen ___ ]]].
eaten has he only green beans
‘He has eaten only green beans.’

However, also AP predicates can undergo ST, resulting into Split Adjective Phrase Topicalization (SAPT) (cf. Corver 1997a; Müller 1998; De Kuthy and Meurers 2001), which will further be ignored here: 6

(7)
[Stolz] ist er vor allem [AP ___ auf seine Kinder].
proud is he especially on his children
‘He is especially proud of his children.’
Finally, yet another type of ST can be discerned, namely Mixed Split Topicalization (MST), which seems to be a blend of SVPT and SNPT:

(8)
[CP
[Mädchen verführt] [C′
hat er schon [viele ___ ]]].
girls seduced has he already many
‘He has already seduced many girls.’ (Fanselow 1987: 102)

MST seems to pose a tough problem for most analyses proposed in the relevant literature because it is unclear how top can form the core part of rem, as the actual split seems to occur at the N-bar-level and not at the level of V-bar.

subsection.heading: 1.3 Interesting problems
subsection.p: Until now, the syntactic literature on ST has mainly focused on the nature of the A-bar-dependency relation between top and rem. Since T is usually analyzed in terms of direct movement, the most straightforward analysis for ST seems to be an analysis in which a main constituent's core (i.e., a subconstituent) is moved into a left-peripheral position. However, this analysis faces particular problems. First, it violates the descriptive generalization that only major, single constituents can be topicalized in German (cf. Thiersch (1978)), which will be dubbed the Single Constituent Condition (SCC) here. The theoretical counterpart of this generalization can be called the Structure Preservation Condition (SPC). The SPC, which has its roots in Emonds (1970), has been reformulated in Chomsky (1986a). It says that maximal projections can only be moved into positions that are apt to host them, such as specifier positions, and that heads can only be moved into X0 positions. Since it is usually assumed that T targets Spec, C, a movement analysis of ST would violate the SPC. In addition, a subphrasal movement analysis faces problems having to do with unexpected overlaps between top and rem, which become visible when top and rem are concatenated into a single constituent. A telling example is the SNPT with “determiner overlap” in (9a):

(9)
a. [CP [ Eine Lösung] [C′
hat er [NP
eine bessere ___ ] als ich]].
a solution has he a better (one) than I
‘As for solutions, he has a better one than I have.’
b. *[NP eine bessere eine Lösung]. (Van Riemsdijk 1989a: 107)

In order to deal with such movement paradoxes (cf. section 2.2), the subphrasal movement analysis has to be supplemented with additional mechanism which will be dealt with in section 3.1. However, different analyses have been proposed to deal with this problem as well (cf. section 3).

With respect to examples like (9a), yet another interesting and complicating aspect of ST deserves to be noticed, namely the considerable amount of dialectal variation with respect to the possible syntactic realizations of top and rem. For example, the SNPT with determiner overlap in (9a) is not accepted by all speakers of German that allow for SNPT, but is usually only acceptable for speakers who hail from the south of Germany, or from Switzerland or Austria.

Yet another interesting aspect of this construction, which has remained almost unnoticed so far, is formed by its striking information-structure properties. One should be aware of the fact that ST is a construction that is stylistically marked and occurs almost exclusively in colloquial language (cf. Kniffka 1996).

STs are mostly characterized by two informational peaks. These two information units are intonationally marked by a rising (L*H) and a falling (H*L) pitch accent respectively and they form a rise-fall contour (RF-contour) (cf. Féry 1993; Van Hoof 2003). The rising pitch accent is marked as ‘/’ and the falling accent as ‘∖’ in front of the accented word, which are written in small caps. The intonational description in (10) is consistent with the prosodic description that has been provided in (2) for unsplit T. Although the difference in strength between the rising and the falling pitch accent has not been specified in (10), the falling accent is perceived as more prominent than the rising one: 7

(10)
[A: Dieses Lehrbuch fand ich ziemlich schlecht. Es gab zwar viele Beispiele . . . ]
‘This textbook, I found rather bad. It contained many examples, though . . .’
aber [ /Erklärungen] gab es dazu [∖keine ___ ].
but explanations gave it to that none
‘but explanations, it contained none.’
(Van Hoof forthcoming)

The rising and the falling pitch accent of the RF-contour signal two foci of attention. The first focus, which is marked by the rise, is located on an element in top and the second one, marked by the fall, is often realized on an element in rem, but can be realized on another constituent in the clause, too. top mostly contrasts with an entity in the context that differs from top with respect to the meaning that is conveyed by the element with the rise and rem sometimes contrasts with another discourse entity as well. Although the examples of ST in this article have not been augmented with a contrast-facilitating context, it is important to be aware of the specific semantico-pragmatic meaning of this construction in German.

Another intriguing but also difficult problem of ST forms its restricted cross-linguistic distribution in comparison with unsplit T. For example, SNPT leads to ungrammatical results in Modern English, Standard Dutch and Scandinavian, which all have (unsplit) T at their disposal.
As becomes clear from (11a), the SNPT in (4) does not have a direct counterpart in English. A well-formed English translation of (4), is provided by (11b):

(11)
a. *[[Beans], [he likes only [green ___ ]]].
b. [[Beans], [he likes only [green ones]]].

In (11b), the left-peripheral NP corefers with the indefinite pronoun ones and not with an empty category. (11b) forms an instance of Hanging Topic Left Dislocation (HTLD) (see chapter 37), a construction in which the left-peripheral constituent does not show connectedness effects with a sentence-internal anaphor.
Although English has VP-preposing, as illustrated in (12), this construction cannot strand arguments. So, SVPT of the German type is excluded in English (cf. (13)):

(12)
They all said that Harry had been eating green beans and . . .
[eating green beans], [he must have been ___ ]!

(13)
They all said that Harry had been eating something and . . .
*[eating], [he must have been ___ green beans].

Of course, the restricted cross-linguistic distribution of ST compared with (unsplit) T can be related to many factors. Ideally, an answer to such a deep question should follow from the proposed analysis. But a lot of hypotheses deserve to be tested before it can be answered in a more than speculative way.

The literature on ST has grown most extensively for German. The emphasis of this article will therefore be on ST in this language (but see section 7 for related phenomena in other languages). Since the two main types of ST, i.e. SNPT and SVPT, have not been treated on a par in the previous literature, the different subtypes of ST will be dealt with separately here as well.

subsection.heading: 2.1 A-bar-characteristics
subsection.p: As demonstrated in detail in Van Riemsdijk (1989a), SNPT exhibits the diagnostic properties of an A-bar-dependency relation. SNPT triggers V-second and leaves behind a gap in rem. Furthermore, the relation between top and rem is island sensitive. The latter is illustrated by the examples in (14). (14a) demonstrates that SNPT is unbounded in principle and (14b) shows that SNPT is sensitive to the Complex-NP Constraint: 8

(14)
a. [Augen] sagt er, [CP
dass sie [schönere ___ ti] hat [als ich]i].
eyes says he that she more beautiful (ones)
has than I
‘As for eyes, he says that she has more beautiful ones than I have.’
b. *[Augen] kenne ich
NP
keine Frau, [CP die [schönere ___ ti] hat [als ich]i]].
eyes know I
no woman who more beautiful (ones)
has than I
‘As for eyes, I know no woman who has more beautiful ones than I have.’
In addition, SNPT shows connectivity effects with respect to binding and morphological case. (15) shows this with respect to Binding Condition A:

(15)
[Bücher von einanderi] sind unsi
[keine ___ ] bekannt.
books of each other are us none
known
‘As for books of each other, none are known to us.’
(Van Riemsdijk 1989a: 115)

Another important property showing that top and rem are A-bar-related is formed by the preservation of ordering restrictions among prenominal adjectives (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1989a). Although the grammatical contrasts shown in (16) are not absolute – for (16b) can be saved by a strong RF-contour and a context in which both top and rem can contrast with another discourse entity 9 – a clear contrast can be observed if the minimal pair (16a, b) is uttered ‘out of the blue’. Since a similar contrast cannot be diagnosed for the corresponding HTLDs (see chapter 37), as can be derived from the translations of the examples in (16), the contrast in (16) can be interpreted as a connectivity effect:

(16)
a. [Ein amerikanisches Auto] kann ich mir [kein neues ___ ] leisten.
an American car can I me no new (one) afford
‘As for an American car, I cannot afford a new one.’
b. * [Ein neues Auto] kann ich mir [kein amerikanisches ___ ] leisten.
a new car can I me no American (one) afford
‘As for a new car, I cannot afford an American one.’
c. Base order: [NP ein [N′ [AP neues] [N′ [AP amerikanisches]N′ [N Auto]]]].
(Van Riemsdijk 1989a: 122)
Another indicator for an A-bar-dependency relation between top and rem is provided by the fact that top in SNPT can licence parasitic gaps (cf. Van Hoof 1997b):

(17)
[Briefe] hat sie [ohne zu Ende e
zu lesen] noch [keine ___ ] weggeworfen.
letters has she without to end
to read yet none away-thrown
‘As for letters, she has not thrown any away yet without finishing reading them.’

Van Riemsdijk (1989a) attributes yet another well-known A-bar property to SNPT, namely the occurrence of Empty Category Principle (ECP) effects (cf. Chomsky 1981), which states that an empty category has to be properly governed. The following tendency is observed: the tighter the structural relation between rem (containing the gap) and the verb, the more easily SNPT can apply. Under the assumption that an accusative object and the main verb have more structural cohesion than a dative object or an unergative subject and the main verb, this tendency is illustrated by the paradigm in (18):

(18)
a. [Einen Wagen] hat er sich [keinen ___ ] gekauft.
a car has he himself none
bought
‘As for a car, he bought himself none.’
b. ?? [Einem älteren Mann] bin ich [keinem ___ ] begegnet.
an older man have I none
met
‘As for an older man, I've met none.’
c. ?* [Ein Experte] hat [keiner ___ ] den Schaden geprüft.
an expert has none
the damage inspected
‘As for an expert, none has inspected the damage.’

However, since ECP effects do not show up as clearly in German as they do in English, it is more appropriate to speak of ECP-like effects in this language. Since these effects can only be perceived if the examples are uttered with the neutral stress pattern (see chapter 49) and can be repaired with the aid of narrow focus on rem (cf. Pafel 1993; Van Hoof 1977a), this A-bar-diagnostic has to be applied with care. ECP-like effects of a similar kind have also been diagnosed for what-for subextraction (see chapter 66) (cf. Oppenrieder 1991b). On the other hand, Pafel (1995) has shown that the syntactic position of rem in SNPT and of the source category in what-for split is more constrained in comparison with the syntactic position of the source category of other split constructions, such as Quantifier Floating or Partitive Split (cf. section 2.3). Therefore, in spite of the ameliorating effect of focus, the pattern outlined in (18) can be interpreted as an indicator for the existence of an A-bar-relation between top and rem.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Movement paradoxes
subsection.p: In general, A-bar-constructions are derived by syntactic movement. However, certain syntactic properties of the internal syntactic make-up of top and rem in SNPT seem to demonstrate that it is highly improbable that top has been moved directly out of rem. Most paradoxes, however, are dialectally constrained.
The first movement paradox that can be observed if the syntactic realizations of top and rem are compared with their combination is determiner overlap (cf. (9), repeated in (19)):

(19)
a. [CP
[Eine Lösung] [C′
hat er [NP
eine bessere ___ ] als ich]].
a solution has he
a better (one) than I
‘As for solutions, he has a better one than I have.’
b. *[NP eine bessere eine Lösung].

The so-called continuatives, i.e., bare plurals and mass nouns, are the most unmarked top forms (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1989a; Kniffka 1996). Although they cannot cause a determiner overlap if they are split (cf. the SNPT in (20a)), a non-matching effect with respect to adjectival inflection can appear, as shown in (20b): 10

(20)
a. [Geld] hat er glaube ich [keines ___ ].
money has he believe I none
‘As for money, I believe he has none.’
b. [kein(*-es) [Geld]].

The strong adjectival inflection on the quantifier is required as soon as the NP in (20) is split. This phenomenon can be explained in the following way: the gap in rem has to be licensed by overt nominal features on the syntactic category that precedes and c-commands the gap. This requirement can be satisfied by the presence of an overt functional head or by inflectional morphology on a preceding adjective. Probably, the head features of the nominal gap have to become visible through the overt part of rem. Exactly the same syntactic conditions appear to hold for the remnant of NP ellipsis (see chapter 22).

Similar mismatches have been observed with respect to the inflectional morphology on adjectives, where one can make a distinction between weak and strong adjectival inflection. This is so because both top and rem are inflected as if they were two independent NPs.
(21) and (22) demonstrate that the adjectival inflections within the split NPs do not always match with the adjectival inflections within the corresponding unsplit NP:

(21)
a. [Polnisch-e Gänse] hat sie [kein-e ___ ] gekauft.
Polish-strong
geese has she no-strong
bought
b. *[Polnisch-en Gänse] hat sie [kein-e ___ ] gekauft.
Polish-weak geese has she no-strong
bought
‘As for Polish geese, she has bought none.’

(22)
a. Sie hat [kein-e polnisch-en Gänse] gekauft.
she has no-strong
Polish-weak
geese bought
b. *Sie hat [kein-e polnisch-e Gänse] gekauft.
she has no-strong
Polish-strong
geese bought
‘She has bought no Polish geese.’
(Fanselow 1988)

The so-called number-disagreement facts, i.e., examples in which top and rem do not agree in number, form a subphrasal movement paradox, too. Note however, that top and rem can disagree only one way: a plural top can take a singular rem, but not the other way around (cf. (23)):

(23)
a. [Autos] hat er nur [eins ___ ].
cars has he only one
‘As for cars, he has only one.’
b. *[(Ein) Auto] hat er sogar [zwei ___ ].
(a) car has he even two
‘As for (a) car, he has even two.’

Other examples feeding the movement paradox are SNPTs with a rem that simply cannot be a source for subphrasal movement because of its specific lexical content. They constitute a so-called non_source for subphrasal movement.

SNPTs containing a non-source are, for example, SNPTs with the non-interrogative quantifier welch- (‘some’) as a rem. This quantifier is only licit if it c-commands an empty category that refers to a continuative: 11

(24)
a. [Pflanzen] hatte sie immer [welche ___ ] im Angebot.
plants had she always some
to offer
‘As for plants, she always had some to offer.’
b. *[NP welche Pflanzen]
A completely different kind of non-source rem, which is also dialectally constrained, is formed by SNPTs with so-called full-NP remnants: 12

(25)
a. [Raubvögel] glaube ich kennt Gereon nur [Bussarde].
birds of prey believe I knows Gereon only buzzards
‘As for birds of prey, Gereon knows only buzzards.’
b. *[NP Raubvögel Bussarde] (Fanselow 1993: 63)
According to Fanselow and Ćavar (2002), another non-source can be found in SPPT, which occurs in certain dialects of southern German:

(26)
a. [In Schlössern] habe ich noch [in keinen ___ ] gewohnt.
in castles have I yet in no (ones) lived
b. *[PP
In keinen in Schlössern ___ ] habe ich noch gewohnt.
in none in castles
have I yet lived
‘I have not yet lived in any castles.’
(Fanselow and Ćavar 2002: 69)

subsection.heading: 2.3 Different kinds of split
subsection.p: Top in SNPT is a non-quantificational indefinite and refers to a property or a kind. 13 Rem restricts the top set by introducing some properties that can be attributed to it, so that the anaphoric relation between top (antecedent) and rem (anaphor) forms a proper subset relation. As a consequence, the ‘whole-to-part’ relation, that is also encoded in unsplit modified NPs, becomes expressed prominently in SNPT.
SNPT can also apply to pseudo partives (cf. (ia) in note 12, which is repeated in (27a) and (27b)):

(27)
a. [Wein] habe ich nur [zwei Flaschen ___ ] dabei.
wine have I only two bottles
with me
‘As for wine, I brought only two bottles.’
b. [Flaschen Wein] habe ich nur [zwei ___ ] dabei.
bottles wine have I only two
with me
‘As for bottles of wine, I brought only two.’

In both split pseudo-partitives, NP1 (rem) functions as a (complex) quantifier to NP2 (top), like in ordinary SNPTs with a quantificational rem. However, preposings that split a real partitive clearly differ from SNPT of pseudo partitives. While in SNPT, a quantificational rem quantifies over an unrestricted set of entities in top, the quantifier in “real” partitive constructions quantifies over a contextually restricted set of entities. But definite or specific tops are not allowed for in SNPT.
Real split-partitive constructions are, for example, Quantifier Floating (cf. (28)) and Partitive Split (cf. (29)):

(28)
[Die Solisten] haben [ ___ alle] viel Beifall bekommen.
the soloists have
all much applause got
‘The soloists all got much applause.’

(29)
[Von uns] hat sich [niemand ___ ] freiwillig gemeldet.
of us has himself nobody
voluntarily announced
‘None of us volunteered.’ (Pafel 1995: 146)

In Quantifier Floating, the fronted NP has to target an A-position before it can target an A-bar position. In Partitive Split, the preposed PP targets an A-bar position. In both constructions, the NP within the preposed PP is definite. Therefore, both Quantifier Floating and Partitive Split are constructions that differ substantially from SNPT. Another difference between Quantifier Floating and Partitive Split, on the one hand, and SNPT and what-for subextraction, on the other hand, is that the source category of the former group of constructions is not subject to the ECP, as becomes apparent from the examples in (28). 14
Yet another kind of T that seems to break up NPs is NP-PP Split (cf. De Kuthy 2002). (30) shows that NP-PP Split can go in two ways: either the NP is preposed and the PP stays behind or vice versa:

(30)
a. [Über Syntax] hat er
[ein Buch ___ ] ausgeliehen.
about syntax has he
a book
borrowed
b. [Ein Buch] hat er [ ___ über Syntax]
ausgeliehen.
a book has he
about syntax
borrowed
‘He borrowed a book about syntax.’ (De Kuthy 2002: 5–7)

In principle, the preposed NP in (30b) could be the underlying core part of the nominal extended projection that is extracted from, as required by our (working) definition of ST (cf. section 1.2). On the other hand, the remnant in NP-PP Split differs from rem in SNPT because the gap in the remnant of NP-PP Split is not licensed by overt agreement morphology. In addition, NP-PP Splits do not give rise to non-matching effects like those in SNPT (cf. De Kuthy 2002: 36).

NP-PP Splits like those in (30a) have been analyzed in terms of subphrasal movement, and NP-PP Splits like those in (30b) in terms of subphrasal movement in combination with remnant movement (cf. Müller 1998) or in terms of phrasal movement preceded by reanalysis (cf. Fanselow 1987; Grewendorf 1989; De Kuthy 2002). 15

In this section, a number of constructions that at first sight seemed to be highly similar to SNPT were listed. However, they appeared to be different from SNPT both on syntactic and semantic grounds. This conclusion is supported by the fact that in contrast with SNPT, Quantifier Floating, Partitive Split and NP-PP Split are also grammatical in English. Table 62.1 summarizes their main similarities and differences. A more exhaustive list of the grammatical properties of SNPT will be provided in section 3.4.

subsection.heading: 3 Syntactic analyses of Split-NP Topicalization
subsection.p: This section provides an overview of the different syntactic analyses that have been proposed in the literature so far and reviews some of their problems. 16 The analyses are subdivided into three groups: (i) subphrasal extraction analyses; (ii) verbal complex extraction analyses; and (iii) phrasal extraction analyses. Although relatively many analyses for SNPT in German are available, fully worked-out proposals are pretty rare. Therefore, the analyses will only be discussed with respect to the core data of SNPT, excluding the data to be presented in section 6.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Subphrasal extraction analyses
subsection.p: Subphrasal movement analyses form the main type of subphrasal extraction analysis for SNPT. 17 Apart from the movement paradoxes listed in section 2.2, this analysis type must say something extra about the SPC on Move α (cf. section 1.3). Then according to this condition (cf. Chomsky 1986a), only heads and maximal projections can be moved, but no intermediate projections. The first subphrasal movement analysis (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1989a), which was developed at a time nominal functional categories had not yet really arrived, does not derive this property from a restriction on the application of Move α, but from a well-formedness condition on S-structure representations. Subphrasal extraction analyses stemming from a more recent date (cf., for example, Tappe 1989; Haegeman 1995b; Kniffka 1996) simply do away with the problem by appealing to the modern version of X-bar-theory that divides constituents into maximal lexical and maximal functional projections. 18 The movement-and-regeneration analysis (M&R analysis) proposed in Van Riemsdijk (1989a) supports a derivational analysis of SNPT in which the movement of intermediate projections is not precluded in principle. Instead of Chomsky's SPC on Move α, van Riemsdijk assumes a well-formedness condition on X-bar-structure representations. The filter dismisses S-structures containing intermediate top projections that are not dominated by another intermediate or maximal projection of the same category and calls into existence some mechanisms of repair that regenerate and relexicalize missing structure in turn. Van Riemsdijk assumes that only languages that allow missing structure to be regenerated can move intermediate projections. In some languages with regeneration, a grammatical formative in top can become relexicalized too. However, the lexical spell-out of regenerated structure is subject to a strict recoverability condition: only words or morphemes that are fully determined by the inherent grammatical features of the nominal lexical head, such as number, gender, and case, can be relexicalized in their unmarked form. (31b, c) demonstrate the effects of regeneration and relexicalization after the A-bar-movement of an intermediate projection to Spec, C has been completed (cf. (31a)):

(31)
a. [CP [N′
Definitiver Beweis]i
[C′
ist bis jetzt [NP
keiner ti] gefunden worden]].
definitive proof
has until now
none found been
b.
Regeneration: [CP [NP [N′ Definitiver Beweis]i] [C′ . . .
c.
Relexicalization: [CP [NP Ein [N′ definitiver Beweis]i] [C′ . . .

As becomes apparent from (31), the possibility of determiner overlap between top and rem in certain varieties of German is accounted for by the possibility of regeneration and relexicalization. The non-matching effects of weak and strong adjectival inflection can only be explained if the spell-out of weak vs. strong inflection is not caused by specific lexical-grammatical features, but is postponed after A-bar-movement has been completed. The same solution, however, cannot be offered for the non-source welche. In order to derive SNPTs with this rem, Van Riemsdijk (1989a: 110) has to make the somewhat dubious assumption that lexical meanings do not have to remain constant throughout the derivation. Also the number-disagreement facts, that are quite common among the different varieties of SNPT, do not follow in a straightforward way from this analysis. Furthermore, an explanation for the existence of full-NP remnants and SPPT would certainly overstrain the mechanisms of regeneration and relexicalization. The existence of MST remains mysterious, too, under this analysis, as Van Riemsdijk (1989a) admits himself in his note 29.

Another subphrasal movement analysis is suggested in Haegeman (1995b: 173–178). Haegeman assumes that the nominal projection consists of different functional layers and that top, being an intermediate maximal projection of rem, can be extracted via the outer specifier of rem. According to Haegeman, the advantage of this implementation of the subphrasal-movement analysis is that the mechanisms of regeneration and relexicalization become superfluous because a layered-NP structure allows NPs to have more internal structure than becomes apparent from surface structure. For instance, the layered-NP structure in (32a) can be used to explain the phenomenon of determiner overlap (cf. (32b)):

Although the determiner overlaps with an indefinite determiner in top and an indefinite determiner or numeral in rem can be analyzed in the same way, this kind of proposal is hardly extendable to data such as (34), as Haegeman notices herself, since NPs of the form eine bessere eine Lösung (‘a better a solution’) are not attested in any variety of Germanic.

In order to motivate a structure for German in which adjectives take NP complements, Haegeman (1995b: 305ff. note 11) suggests a parallel with the phenomenon of double definiteness in Hebrew and Modern Greek (cf. section 7.1).

A subphrasal-movement analysis combined with a base-generated top is sketched in Giusti (1993: 148–154). Giusti suggests an extension of the Contrastive Left Dislocation (CLD) analysis of T (see chapter 37) to SNPT. 20 In this analysis, top is base-generated in left-dislocated position and is co-indexed with a moved empty operator in Spec, C that binds an empty category in rem:
(35) [CP [F [NP NP]]i [CP Opi . . . [VP . . . [QP Q0 ti] . . . ]]]

Giusti assumes that the moved empty NP-operator has been assigned partitive case by Q0 and can be lexicalized as da (‘there’) or solche (‘such’) in German. The empty operator in Spec, C and the variable in rem have the same categorial and projectional features because this chain results from movement. The left-dislocated top and the movement chain become co-indexed through binding and, therefore, no full identity of categorial and projectional features is required. As a consequence, this analysis opens perspectives to explain SNPTs with determiner overlap or number-disagreement. It remains unclear, however, how SNPTs with full-NP remnants could be accounted for. On the other hand, if the moved empty operator is assumed to be pro (cf. Cardinaletti 1986), the generalization that the licensing conditions for the empty nominal part in rem are identical to the ones for the gap in elliptic NPs follows as a matter of fact. Giusti's analysis also complies with the SCC and with the SPC. For a slightly different CLD-analysis for SNPT, see Van Hoof (1997a).

subsection.heading: 3.2 Extraction of a verbal complex from VP
subsection.p: In one of the first analyses for SNPT (cf. Fanselow (1987: 98–107)), the operation of T is preceded by a process of reanalysis between the object and the verb. In this reanalysis-and-movement analysis (R&M analysis), SNPT and MST are analyzed in the same way. The preconditions for the application of reanalysis are that the to-be-reanalyzed NP is adjacent to the verb and that the NP is dominated by VP. The process of reanalysis is illustrated in (36):

(36)
a. D-str1:
[VP [NP viele Mädchen] [V verführt]]
b. D-str2 after reanalysis:
[VP [NP viele ti] [VC Mädcheni verführt]]
The SNPT and the MST in (37) are derived by A-bar-movement of the verbal complex (VC) to Spec, C:

(37)
a. [VC
Mädchen]i
hat er schon [viele ti] verführt.
girls has he already many
seduced
‘As for girls, he has already seduced many.’
b. [VC
Mädchen verführt]i
hat er schon [viele ti].
girls seduced has he already many
‘As for having seduced girls, he has already seduced many.’
(Fanselow 1987: 102)

Since reanalysis can only apply to VP-internal constituents that are left adjacent to the verb, this analysis predicts that SNPTs with dative and nominative rems are generally less well-formed than SNPTs with accusative rems. Therefore, the contrast between passivized and ergative-subject rems, which can form a rem easily, and agentive-subject rems, which can only form a rem if they are focused (cf. section 2.1), is predicted by this analysis under the assumption that passivized, ergative and focused agentive subjects are realized VP-internally (cf. Diesing 1992b).

Unfortunately, this proposal has not been worked out in every detail. For instance, Fanselow remains vague about the syntactic category of the verbal complex in (36b). Is it a complex word or a phrasal constituent? Related to this problem, the projectional feature of the incorporated part of the NP is left unspecified, too. It is also not clear how the empty category in (36b) can be bound, since it c-commands its antecedent after reanalysis, but this is a general problem for certain analyses of N-incorporation. Fanselow (1987) does not describe either how the SNPT in (37a) can be derived. If it is indeed the verbal complex that has been preposed to Spec, C, the verb verführt (‘seduced’) must probably have been extracted to the right before T applies.

A serious problem for this analysis is that the linear adjacency condition on reanalysis is not always respected. If, as suggested by (36b), only the second half of the source NP, i.e., the part that is adjacent to the verb, can be reanalyzed, we would expect Bücher von Chomsky to be the only possible top-candidate in (38) (cf. (38a)), but this does not turn out to be the case (cf. (38b)):

(38)
a. [Bücher von Chomsky] hat er [keine ___ ] gekauft.
books of Chomsky has he none
bought
‘As for books of Chomsky, he bought none.’
b. [Bücher] hat er [keine ___ von Chomsky] gekauft.
books has he none of Chomsky bought
‘As for books, he bought none of Chomsky.’

Apart from these problems, this analysis fails to solve the same problems that were problematic for derivational N-bar-movement analyses, too. A similar analysis that overcomes some of these problems has been presented in Fanselow (1993).

In order to derive SNPT and MST on a par, Fanselow (1993) proposes the base-generated-VP-plus-chain analysis, in which a base-generated VP is co-indexed through a binding chain with an empty category in the middle-field. MST and SNPT are assigned the same underlying structures as shown in (39a, b):

row.entry: [CP [VP1 topNP [V1 e]]i [C′ . . . [VP2 . . . remNP . . . [VP1 [NP e] V1]i V2]]].

subsection.p: In SNPT (cf. (39b)), the verbal head of the VP projection in Spec, C is represented by an empty category, and is overtly realized in the middle-field instead. Unlike in the former split-VP analysis, i.e., the R&M-analysis of Fanselow (1987), topNP and remNP are base-generated as two independent NPs in the sentence.

The advantages of a base-generation analysis are clear: split NPs do not have to constitute a continuous NP in underlying structure. Therefore, both variants in (38) are predicted to be grammatical. The existence of non-sources, including full-NP remnants, follows as a matter of fact.

How does this analysis fare with respect to the theta-criterion? The standard solution GB-theory has to offer for similar phenomena, like clitic doubling (see chapter 14), is that theta-roles are not assigned to syntactic constituents, but to syntactic chains. But this procedure of theta-role-assignment cannot be adopted for topNP and remNP in (39a, b) because the split NPs do not form an NP-chain, since they are included in constituents that form links of a VP-chain. Nevertheless, the split NPs form different instantiations of the same argument. Therefore, Fanselow (1993) adopts a more refined version of the theta-criterion than is usually assumed in GB-theory:
(40) In the extended projection of a (base-generated) VP, an argument license can be issued only once.

The notion argument license in (40) does not only cover theta-assignment, i.e. the closing of an argument position, but also its modification. It is also assumed that although an argument slot can be closed only once, it can be modified repeatedly before closure. In the representational chains of co-indexed VPs in (39), topNP receives a modification license from the (c)overt verb V1 that heads the topicalized VP, while rem is assigned a theta-role by the (c)overt verb V2 in the predicating clause. In this way, top and rem form two different realizations of one and the same argument of the complex predicate that is formed by V1 and V2.

In these two proposals of Fanselow, the similarities between SNPT and MST are captured by means of an almost identical structural representation. But this analysis may well turn out a means too powerful to express the common properties between SNPT and MST. Intuitively, SNPT seems to be a more basic kind of ST than MST. But in these two analyses, SNPT ends up with an analysis that is at least as intricate as the one for MST.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Phrasal extraction analyses
subsection.p: Fanselow (1988) proposes an analysis in which two NPs are base generated in the middle-field and one of them is topicalized. In the base-generated structure (cf. (41a)), rem is in a VP-internal A-position and top, an indefinite property-denoting NP, is adjoined to V0. The corresponding S-structure that is derived after T is specified in (41b):

(41)

[NP

[NP polnischen Gänse] [V0
gekauft]]].
she has
none

‘She didn't buy any Polish geese.’

[C′

[NP

Polish geese

‘As for Polish geese, she bought none.’ (Fanselow 1988: 103f)

It is assumed furthermore that only rem, which is base-generated in the regular A-position outside of the domain of V0, is assigned a theta-role. In order to satisfy the Principle of Full Interpretation (cf. Chomsky 1986b), which says that every link in a chain must make its own contribution to the meaning of a sentence, it is assumed that top modifies rem by binding pro in rem. In this way, the fronting of top out of the complex verb into Spec, C is forced to apply and pro can only be bound by the preposed top and by no other c-commanding constituent in the sentence.

The idea to treat rem as an elliptic NP in which the elided site is represented as a pronominal category was newly introduced in Fanselow (1988), who adopted the analysis of Olsen (1987) for ellipsis in German NPs. Similar ideas were substantiated and became more influential by the work of Lobeck (1995) (see chapter 22).

Fanselow's (1988) proposal, which has been adopted recently in Van Geenhoven (1998) and Krifka (1998b), avoids many problems that are inherent to subphrasal-movement analyses. The paradox that SNPT shows properties of movement and of base-generation at the same time receives a straightforward explanation by the two independently base-generated NPs representing the same argument and of which only one is A-bar-moved.

However, some details in the analysis remain obscure. Although Fanselow (1988: 105) states that not only non-referential NPs but also directional PPs can be adjoined to V0 in German, he remains silent about the details of a deep structure for a VP in which both types of predicative constituents occur at the same time. Another problem for this analysis is that usually only bare nouns, i.e. bare plurals, mass nouns, or bare count nouns, take part in word formation processes and that, therefore, singular-count tops with a lexicalized indefinite determiner are not predicted by this analysis. A general problem for analyses that allow one argument to be represented by more than one syntactic constituent is that they do not have a straightforward answer as yet to the question of how adjectival ordering restrictions holding in the corresponding unsplit NP are preserved among top and rem.

Fanselow and Ćavar (2002) offer yet another phrasal-movement analysis for SNPT in German, i.e. the so-called copy-and-distributed-deletion analysis (C&DD analysis). In the Minimalist Program (cf. Chomsky 1995c), movement is analyzed as a combination of two distinct operations, i.e. Copy and Delete (C&D). According to Fanselow and Ćavar, one of the advantages of a movement analysis in which deletion does not form an automatic sequel of copying, is that the existence of a construction like SNPT comes more or less for free. They propose to derive SNPT by a special application of C&D, in which the deletion operation does not affect the entire downstairs copy, but the upstairs and the downstairs copy in a partial and complementary way. This is what they call “distributed deletion.” (42) compares an instantiation of unsplit movement (42a) with an instantiation of split movement in terms of C&D (the phonetically deleted parts have been struck out):

(42)
a. [viele Birnen]2
. . . [viele
Birnen]1
. . . (unsplit movement)
many pears . . . many pears
b. [viele
Birnen]2
. . . [viele Birnen]1
. . . (split movement)
many pears . . . many pears

Both phrasal-movement types are assumed to be licit because in both cases, i.e., in (42a) and (42b), the economy Principle of Pronunciation, saying that material should not be pronounced twice, has been respected. It is also assumed that only those syntactic categories of the copy have to be visible in the upstairs copy whose features are checked there, and that the remaining part can be deleted in accordance with the Principle of Pronunciation. Furthermore, the C&DD-analysis is enriched with additional principles that can be ranked differently for the different varieties of German. In the analysis of Fanselow and Ćavar, split-constituent movement is marked because C&DD violates the Principle of Contiguity, which says that material that has been merged as a single phrase should remain contiguous at spell-out. However, a violation of the Principle of Contiguity is possible in German, because this language still has another principle, which is higher ranked and which allows a single constituent with two or more syntactic features to check its features with different heads before spell-out.

SNPT is further assumed to be information-structure driven. The authors assume that the information structure of SNPT in German is determined in the following way: rem has to be focused and top has to be a topic or a secondary focus. In addition, these information-structural requirements of top and rem are assumed to be encoded as strong semantico-pragmatic operator features that have to be checked by two different functional heads: a focus head F1 and a topic (or secondary-focus) head F2 (cf. also Krifka 1998b). So the to-be-split phrase XP first moves into Spec, F1, where the focus feature is checked and then into Spec, F2 where the other pragmatic feature is checked. 21 (43a) specifies the result after the two subsequent copying operations have applied, and (43b) after distributed deletion. It is assumed that the operations of distributed deletion do not apply before the copying operations have been completed.

(Fanselow and Ćavar 2002: (67))

For a great part, the explanatory force of this analysis stems from the different possible rankings of principles. For example, the phenomenon of determiner-overlap, which violates the Principle of Pronunciation, is viewed as a natural consequence of a principle that requires the phonetic string dominated by an NP to meet the lexical and morphological well-formedness conditions for NPs. Since determiner overlap violates the Principle of Pronunciation, this principle is assumed to be ranked higher than the Principle of Pronunciation in a minority of dialects. The number-disagreement facts are accounted for in a similar way. So, many problems that have been identified as movement paradoxes in section 2.2 receive an optimality-theoretic explanation in this analysis. The C&DD-analysis suggests a ‘regeneration and relexicalization’-like solution for the possibility of SPPT, but it has no explanation to offer for the possibility of full-NP remnants in some dialects. Furthermore, this analysis provides no explanation for MST.

Yet another phrasal-movement analysis for SNPT, which – like any phrasal-movement analysis – obeys the SPC as a matter of fact, is an analysis that base-generates split NPs as members of a paratactic NP, i.e., the apposition analysis. This analysis is discussed in Van Hoof (1997b, forthcoming) for German and Brabant Dutch. 22 Van Hoof relates SNPT with a complex-NP construction, named Restrictive Elliptic Appositive (REA) in Van Riemsdijk (1998a), which is attested in some colloquial varieties of German.

(44)
[[Unterhosen] [dreckige]] solltest du waschen.
underpants dirty should you wash
(Van Riemsdijk 1998a: 19)

According to Van Riemsdijk (1998a), a REA forms a complex NP consisting of two independent NPs, of which the second one is elliptic. Van Hoof observes that in REAs, the second NP modifies the first one by specifying a subkind. Therefore, the antecedent/anaphor relation between the two NPs in a REA is of the same semantic type as between top and rem in SNPT (cf. section 2.3). Van Hoof argues that in SNPT, the split NPs are base-generated as a REA headed by the first NP. As shown in (45), the individual members of a REA form two autonomous NPs, for both NPs need a lexical determiner if they are headed by a singular count-noun:

(45)

‘As for underpants, I have fortunately still found some clean ones.’

Many grammatical properties of SNPT can be derived correctly by the apposition analysis, such as the possibility of determiner overlap, non-source and full-NP rems as well as the possibility of number-disagreement facts.
However, some problems still remain. For example, this analysis does not predict the possibility of bare singular count-noun tops (cf. note 10). 23

On the other hand, the apposition analysis is one of the very few analyses that predicts the possibility of SPPT, at least in some dialects of German. Van Riemsdijk (1998a) provides an example of a REA that consists of two PPs (cf. (47)). By splitting up the REA in this example, the SPPT in (48) can be derived:

subsection.heading: 3.4 Summary
subsection.p: Although the analyses developed for SNPT in the past can be characterized as highly inventive, none of the analyses can account for all the different possible syntactic realizations of top and rem. Table 62.2 provides a bird's-eye view of the different grammatical properties of SNPT, as discussed in section 2, as well as a list of the most important analyses of this grammatical construction, as discussed in this section.

In relation to the restricted cross-linguistic distribution of SNPT within the Germanic language family, another interesting point of comparison has a bearing on the factor(s) that are held responsible for the occurrence of this construction in a particular language variety. Table 62.3 lines up the parameters that are implied by the different proposals.

subsection.heading: 4 Syntactic properties of Split-VP Topicalization
subsection.p: In SVPT, a core part of a complex verbal predicate (i.e., top) is extracted to the pre-field, where it is immediately followed by the fronted finite verb, while at least one of its verbal dependents, forming rem together with the c-commanded gap, is stranded in the clause. This is illustrated by the contrast between the well-formed SVPTs in (51) and the ill-formed ones in (52): 24

(51)
a. [Verkaufen] [wird er das Pferd ___ müssen].
sell will he the horse have to
‘He will have to sell the horse.’
b. [Verkaufen müssen] [wird er das Pferd ___ ].
sell have to will he the horse
(De Kuthy and Meurers 2001)

(52)
a. *[Das Pferd müssen] [wird er ___ verkaufen ___ ].
the horse have to will he sell
b. *[Müssen] [wird er das Pferd verkaufen ___ ].
have to will he the horse sell
‘He will have to sell the horse.’

In a way, the syntactic properties of SVPT are reminiscent of SNPT. The X-bar-status of the fronted split VPs in (51) has been left unspecified. Under a direct-movement analysis, the topicalized constituents cannot be maximal extended verbal projections, at least not without an additional stipulation. Therefore, SVPTs pose the same problems to the SPC and SCC as SNPT.

An analysis for SVPT must also be compatible with a plausible structural representation for the complex verbal predicate in the middle-field before the application of T. T is often used as a constituent test. However, it appears impossible to draw any firm conclusions about the constituency of complex verbal predicates on the basis of SVPT. For example, on the basis of (51a), one would conclude that the embedded verb combines with the direct object before it combines with other verbs. However, (51b) contradicts this conclusion. It shows that the main verb can also be combined with other verbs before it combines with the direct object. So on the basis of SVPT, it can only be concluded that there is no single bracketing available for the deep structure of the predicating clause. This seems to be an undesired result and has become known as the problem of spurious ambiguity (cf. Nerbonne 1994).

subsection.heading: 4.1 A-bar-properties and movement paradoxes
subsection.p: SVPT is island-sensitive, as briefly shown by (53), which violates the Complex-NP Condition, and by (54), which constitutes a violation of the Subject Condition:

(53)

this book to have to difficult
‘To have to read this book is difficult.’

So SVPT also creates an A-bar-relation between top and rem. Movement paradoxes are not that numerous as with SNPT, though they do occur. Haider (1990) brings up an example set with argument clauses that can be interpreted as a movement paradox. In German, non-topicalized argument clauses have to be realized in the post-field and cannot appear in the middle-field at surface structure, as shown in (55). However, the two SVPTs in (56) can only be derived if the transformational rules T and extraposition are not ordered. Then, in (56a), extraposition must have applied after T and in (56b), extraposition must have applied before T, at least under the assumption that SVPT is derived by direct movement: 25

(55)
a. dass er wohl fragen müssen wird, [ob wir einverstanden sind].
that he surely ask have to will whether we agreed are
b. *dass er wohl fragen [ob wir einverstanden sind] müssen wird.

‘that he surely will have to ask whether we agree.’ (Haider 1990b: 95)

(56)
a. [Fragen, ob wir einverstanden sind] [wird er wohl ___ müssen].
ask whether we agreed are will he surely have to
b. [Fragen] wird er wohl ___ müssen, [ob wir einverstanden sind].

‘He will surely have to ask whether we agree.’

Weerman (1989) and Zwart (1993) note that in some VPTs the dummy verb to do shows up naturally in the second position of a topicalized sentence, though it is really awkward in a stylistically unmarked declarative sentence. A similar contrast can be constructed for SVPT, too: 26

(57)
a. [Kochen] [tut er nur vegetarische Gerichte ___ ].

‘As for cooking, he cooks only vegetarian dishes.’
b. *Er tut nur vegetarische Gerichte kochen.
he does only vegetarian dishes cook
‘He cooks only vegetarian dishes.’
In spite of these movement paradoxes, the relation between top and rem can be characterized as of the A-bar-type.

subsection.heading: 4.2 The gap is governed by a restructuring verb
subsection.p: A fundamental observation about SVPT is that this construction requires a complex VP consisting of at least two verbs (cf. Haider 1990b). In addition, the governor of the gap of the preposed split VP has to be a restructuring verb (see chapter 75).

The individual verbs in a restructured complex VP are more cohesively connected than verbs that form part of a verbal complex that includes non-restructuring verbs. The cohesion property of restructured VPs becomes apparent from a number of grammatical properties, 27 among others the possibility of SVPT (cf. (58)). In SVPTs, the gap corresponding to top has to be governed by an (optional) restructuring verb (cf. Müller 1998 and the references therein). For instance, wollen (‘to want’), which governs the gap in (58a), forms an obligatorily restructuring verb, versucht (‘to try’) in (58b) an optionally restructuring verbal participle and abgelehnt (‘refused’) in (58c) an obligatory non-restructring verbal participle: 28

(58)
a. [Lesen] [hat keiner das Buch ___ wollen].
read has no one the book want
‘No one has wanted to read the book.’
b. [Zu lesen] [hat keiner das Buch ___ versucht].
to read has no one the book tried
‘No one has tried to read the book.’
c. *[Zu lesen] [hat keiner das Buch ___ abgelehnt].
to read has no one the book rejected
‘No one has rejected to read the book.’

subsection.heading: 4.3 The division of arguments among TOP and REM
subsection.p: If SVPT were really similar to SNPT, one would expect that the base order of arguments of a restructured VP would be reflected in the division of arguments among top and rem, by analogy with the preservation of adjectival ordering restrictions in SNPT. As argued in Haider (1993), the base order of arguments in non-topicalized sentences is determined by the rank of argument variables in the lexical argument structure of a verb. So, one would predict the effect of a condition like that in (59) to become perceivable somehow: 29

(59)
No-Theta-Crossing Constraint (NTCC):
Argument A cannot be in top if there is an argument B in rem and A >>> B in the argument structure of the restructured VP.

Clear contrasts with respect to the NTCC can be observed for restructured VPs that select a direct object and a dative or genetive object. As can be viewed from the base order in (60a), the genetive object must be ranked lower in the lexical argument structure of the complex VP than the direct object. The contrast between (60b) and (60c) shows the effect of the NTCC: 30

(60)
a. Man sollte seinen Vater nie eines Mordes beschuldigen. (Base order)
one should his father never the-gen
murder-gen
accuse
‘One should never accuse his father of murder.’

subsection.heading: 5 Syntactic analyses of Split-VP Topicalization
subsection.p: The following two main types of analysis have been proposed for SVPT in German in the past: (i) the remnant-movement (RM) analysis, and (ii) extraction of a VP shell. Both analyses somehow build a bridge between the phenomenon of Scrambling and the possibility of SVPT. The fact that SVPT only occurs in the Germanic languages with Scrambling, such as German and Dutch, hints at this correlation. 33 The two analyses capture this correlation in slightly different ways.

subsection.heading: 5.1 The RM analysis
subsection.p: The RM analysis for SVPT was launched in Thiersch (1985) and developed further by den Besten and Webelhuth (1990) and by Müller (1998). The analysis proceeds in two steps: (i) an internal argument is scrambled (i.e., moved) out of a dominating VP, and (ii) the VP is topicalized (i.e., moved directly) into Spec, C:
In this way, the SPC is satisfied and also the spurious-ambiguity problem is solved.

In the RM analysis, it is assumed that the domain of the restructured VP also delimits the syntactic domain for Scrambling (cf. (i) in note 28), as also becomes apparent from the minimal pair in (68):

A theoretical problem for this analysis is the problem of unbound traces. According to the Proper Binding Condition (PBC), traces have to be c-commanded by their antecedent. Since top in SVPT contains an unbound trace, the PBC is expected to preclude SVPT under this analysis.

Den Besten and Webelhuth (1990) propose to alleviate the effect of the PBC for SVPT by allowing unbound argument traces in top to be reconstructed into their base position and as a consequence, to become invisible for the PBC. 34 Contrasts like those in (69) are explained in this way:

Müller (1998) argues that the PBC can be fully dispensed with in a strictly derivational theory of movement that adopts the main premises of the Minimalist Program (cf. Chomsky 1995c). 35

Another theoretical problem for the RM-analysis is formed by the so-called ‘anti-freezing’ effects. The Freezing Principle (see chapter 28) states that extraction of a phrase α from another phrase &bgr; is only possible if &bgr; occurs in situ and is not a moved category itself. Therefore, extraction from the (overt) scrambled rem in SVPT is predicted to be always ungrammatical, contrary to fact. For example, the Freezing Priniciple correctly rules out the SVPT in (70a), but incorrectly excludes the SVPT in (70b):

(70)

Given the sum of facts in (70), it cannot be claimed that every scrambled phrase forms an island for extraction, since the string-vacuously scrambled rems do not. Therefore, Den Besten and Webelhuth (1990) propose that the general ban against extraction from adjoined phrases can be alleviated if the PP is adjacent to the reconstructed verb.

Müller (1998: 205ff.) provides a different account for the contrast in (70). According to him, the rem PP in (70b) must have undergone a different kind of movement in this example, namely ‘string-vacuous’ extraposition, that exempts it from inducing a freezing effect. However, as Müller admits himself, this solution does not seem to be fully satisfactory either.

Müller (1998) explains the asymmetry between topicalized and scrambled split VPs (cf. section 4.4) – i.e., that split VPs can be topicalized but cannot be scrambled – by the Principle of Unambiguous Domination (PUD). The PUD says that remnant XPs cannot undergo a particular type of movement if the antecedent of the unbound trace in XP has undergone the same type of movement (Müller 1998: 241).

We will now focus on a different problem for the RM-analysis, namely on its tenet that rems are evacuated from VP by a movement type that equals Scrambling. The strongest possible prediction of the RM-analysis is that elements that can be scrambled can be stranded as rems and vice versa. But it can be argued that this premise cannot be upheld for at least three reasons: (i) the NTCC does not comply with it; (ii) certain elements cannot be scrambled, but can still be stranded as rems; and (iii) certain stranded elements that can be scrambled can also be stranded with an ‘in situ’ interpretation.

Although different types of Scrambling can be distinguished in West Germanic (see chapter 43), most Scrambling types change the base order of arguments. Therefore, the effect of the NTCC (cf. (59)) comes somewhat as a surprise, since in the RM analysis Scrambling precedes T. The proponents of the RM analysis do not specify which Scrambling type is supposed to be relevant for their analysis. The type of Scrambling that can apply after T has been completed, on the other hand, is allowed to permute arguments (cf. note 29).
A constituent type which it is generally assumed cannot be scrambled, but that can still be stranded as a rem, is formed by negated indefinites, as shown in (71):

Another point that weakens the RM analysis is that in this analysis any VP node can form the target of remnant T, which makes it hard to falsify the analysis. As a consequence, the preposed remnant VP is labeled ‘α’ in order to remain uncommitted about the categorial features of the remnant VP (cf. Müller 1998: 214).
An HPSG analysis that resembles the RM analysis in many respects has been proposed by Hinrichs et al. (1994).

subsection.heading: 5.2 Extraction of a VP shell
subsection.p: Another possible way by means of which a movement analysis can meet the requirements that are set by the SPC and the spurious-ambiguity problem is to conceive a maximal (complex) VP as a cascade of layered VPs and by extracting one of the VP shells, as proposed for instance in Frey and Tappe (1991), Fanselow (1993), Haider (1993, 1994a):

(73)
weil [VP
jemand [VP

‘because someone promises a girl a bunch of flowers.’

This type of analysis assumes that theta-roles cannot only be assigned in a head–sister configuration, but in a Vmax–sister configuration as well. In addition, it is assumed that the arguments are merged in the same order as in the lexical argument structure of the main verb.

In the analysis of Frey and Tappe (1991), elements that are theta-marked in the head–sister configuration are restricted to non-depictive predicative elements, resultatives and directional PPs. The syntactic position of these elements is relatively fixed, which appears from the fact that they cannot be scrambled with a flat intonation. According to Frey and Tappe, the fact that these elements cannot be stranded in SVPT (cf. (74)) is predicted by their analysis. However as shown by (75), these SVPTs become perfectly grammatical if the predicative element is made heavier, for instance by means of focus:

(74)
*[Gegessen] [hat er den Teller leer ___ ].
eaten has he the plate empty
‘He has eaten the plate empty.’

(75)
[Gegessen] [hat er den Teller nur halb leer ___ ].
eaten has he the plate only half empty
‘He has eaten the plate only half empty.’

In the analysis of Haider (1990b, 1993, 1994a), top is base-generated as a (small VP) in Spec, C and co-indexed with an empty category in the clause with identical categorial but with not necessarily identical level features (cf. note 17 for a reference to a similar analysis of SNPT, which violates the Chain Uniformity Condition as well).

Haider (1993, 1994a) assumes that in restructured VPs, the argument structures of the individual verbs have been unified and that the restructured VP has a complex projection base. A complex projection base contains more than one lexical head in the syntactic projection, which comes about through head-to-head adjunction, while the arguments of the verbal complex form segments of the maximal projection of the complex head.

Given this structural representation of restructured VPs, the SVPT in (76a) can be derived. However, the derivation in (76b) is problematic because of a conflict of requirements (cf. also Haider 1993: 282). On the one hand, top has to be a maximal projection – not only because of the SPC, but also since it contains a direct object – while on the other hand, the empty category bound by top has to be a head, since it must form a complex head with the fronted restructuring verb haben (‘to have’):

A similar kind of analysis within the framework of HPSG has been proposed in Nerbonne (1994) and De Kuthy and Meurers (2001). They propose an analysis that makes use of an argument-raising mechanism encoded in lexical rules.

A modernized version of the VP-shell movement analysis is proposed in Fanselow (2002) and is called the predicate-raising analysis (PR-analysis). In this analysis, a maximal VP is directly moved into Spec, C and each VP shell is dominated by its own lexical head. The traditional assumption that theta-roles of X0 must be assigned to elements within XP has also been dismissed. In these three variants of the VP-shell-extraction analysis, there is a direct link between SVPT and the base-generated structure for restructured VPs (see chapter 75). The fact that German (and Dutch) allow for SVPT, but English does not (cf. the VPT in (12) vs. the ungrammatical SVPT in (13)), is attributed to the German-specific middle-field structure in which arguments can be base-generated as sisters of a VP. A clear advantage of these analyses is that stranded arguments are not predicted to be islands a priori because they can be in base-generated position. For the same reason, the concept of ‘string-vacuous’ Scrambling comes more or less for free in these analyses, so that they do not imply a mismatch between stranding and Scrambling. However, the latter point does not pertain to the PR analysis, since in this analysis free word order is base generated. Therefore, this analysis does not make a distinction between ‘string-vacuous’ Scrambling and Scrambling that permutes arguments, just like the RM analysis. Fanselow (2002: 105ff.) appears to draw this conclusion himself.

subsection.heading: 6 Different landing sites for Split Topicalization
subsection.p: Until now, we have only taken into account STs in which the split constituent has been extracted to a position right in front of the finite verb in main clauses. However, ST can also target different positions, which this section will pass in review.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Split Scrambling
subsection.p: It has been noted in Grewendorf (1989) and Neeleman (1994a) that split NPs can also be preposed in embedded clauses, a type of ST that will be referred to as Split Scrambling. (79) and (80) provide some examples of Split-NP Scrambling:

(79)
a. weil er [Kleider] immer [dreckige ___ ] anhat
because he clothes always dirty (ones) wears
b. weil [Kleider] er immer [dreckige ___ ] anhat

(Grewendorf 1989: 27)

(80)

gives

gives
‘that Hans does not give many books of such authors even to his son’
(Neeleman 1994: 86)

(79) and (80) show the split-scrambled NP can either precede or follow the definite subject. According to Neeleman (1994a), the examples in (80) form instances of Focus Scrambling, an A-bar-kind of Scrambling that triggers the rise-fall contour with a rise on the preposed phrase. 37

Although split VPs, like split NPs, are not allowed to undergo neutral Scrambling (cf. section 4.4), they can undergo Focus Scrambling, again with the rise-fall contour, giving rise to Split-VP Scrambling:

(81)
dass [so geliebt] [die Maria nur er hat]

‘that only he loved Maria to such a degree’
(Hinterhölzl 2002: 140)

subsection.heading: 6.2 Split Contrastive Left Dislocation
subsection.p: Van Hoof (1997a, 1997b) demonstrates that in Brabant Dutch split NPs cannot only undergo ST to the position right in front of the finite verb, but Contrastive Left Dislocation (CLD) (see chapter 37) as well. This type of ST, in which the finite verb ends up in third position, is named Split-CLD. As shown in (83), SNPT and Split-NP CLD (SNPCLD) occur side by side in Brabant Dutch:

(83)
Brabant Dutch:

‘As for cows, he has quite a lot in the rearmost meadow.’
(Van Hoof 1997a: 280)

As becomes apparent from (83), SNPCLD differs from SNPT by a right-adjacent d(emonstrative)-pronoun (i.e. a so-called d-pronoun) whose &phis;-features agree with top. As shown in Van Hoof (1997a), top and rem are A-bar-related through the d-pronoun. Except for the presence of the d-pronoun, SNPT and SNPCLD in Brabant Dutch roughly have the same grammatical properties as SNPT in German. 38

Examples of Split-VP CLD (SVPCLD) have also been observed for different varieties in West Germanic. Zwart (1993) provides an example for Dutch (84) and Fanselow (1993) mentions similar examples for German (85):

(84)

(Zwart 1993: 109)

(85)

‘Peter will actually not give the book to me.’

‘One should better not give a child such books.’

subsection.heading: 7 Work on related phenomena in other languages
subsection.p: Within the generative framework, SNPT and related split-NP-preposing constructions have been investigated in some depth for Modem Greek, Polish, Serbo-Croatian, and Russian. These constructions are typical of two registers, namely literary prose and spoken language. Most studies take into account only the latter variety, and so does this section. These languages also allow for split-NP preposings that seem to be of a slightly different type, since not the constituents’ core but their left branch are preposed. In this type of split-NP preposing, for example, an adjective can be preposed, while the noun stays behind. Fanselow and Ćavar (2002) introduce the term pull split for this kind of split-NP preposing, a term that will be adopted here.

subsection.heading: 7.1 Split-NP preposing in Modern Greek
subsection.p: Androutsopoulou (1998) proposes a RM analysis for split-NP preposing in Modern Greek. Androutsopoulou only discusses split-NP preposings of the pull-split type with a definite top (cf. (90b)). The unsplit variant is provided in (90a):

(90)
a. Idha [to kokkino forema].
I saw the red dress
‘I saw the red dress.’
b. [To
kokkino] idha [ ___ forema].
the red I saw
dress
‘It is the red dress that I saw.’
(Androutsopoulou 1998: 2)
Androutsopoulou demonstrates that the relation between top and rem exhibits properties of A-bar-movement. She proposes the analysis in (91) for the split-NP preposing in (90b):

(91)
[FocP [DP
To kokkino ti]j

forema]i X0 [VP tk tj]]].

(Androutsopoulou 1998: 9)

According to the derivation depicted in (91), firstly the overt part of rem, apparently remaining in situ in (90b), is scrambled as a subconstituent out of the unsplit NP to the specifier of a verbal functional head, i.e. X0, which hosts a clitic in clitic doubling constructions. In a second step, top – i.e., the remnant DP containing the trace of forema ‘dress’ – is moved in its entirety into the specifier of a left-peripheral focus phrase (FocP). In this way, a potential violation of the Left Branch Condition (see chapter 66) is avoided. The island and connectivity effects are caused by the second step of remnant movement.

Although Androutsopoulou explicitly notes that the preposed NP remnant, i.e., top, has the syntactic appearance of an independent elliptic NP, the relation between the gap in top and its antecedent rem is one of movement in this analysis. However, exactly this observation and the fact that rem can also be preceded by a determiner (cf. (92)), as in independent NPs, lead Mathieu and Sitaridou (2003) to adopt an analysis that departs from a base-generated paratactic NP “[[to forema] [to kokkino]]” (cf. also Devine and Stephens 2000 for a similar analysis of split NPs in Ancient Greek): 40

(Horrocks and Stavrou 1987: 91)

Mathieu and Sitaridou (2003) relate the phenomenon of determiner spreading (or: ‘double definiteness’ (cf. section 3.1)) in Modern Greek to split-NP preposing in this language. They propose that the two paratactic NPs in a determiner-spreading structure form a small clause. One NP forms a referential elliptic DP-predicate; the other NP, which is of the category NP and may contain an expletive determiner, forms its subject. The predicate DP of the small clause undergoes predicate inversion and raises to an outer specifier position in order to be licensed. (93) shows the determiner-spreading structure for the paratactic NP ‘[[to forema] [to kokkino]]’ as proposed by Mathieu and Sitaridou (2003: (25)): 41
(93) [DP [DP To kokino e]i [SC [NP to forema] ti]].
The structure in (93) forms the point of departure for the derivation of split-NP preposing in (90b). 42

subsection.heading: 7.2 Split-NP and split-PP preposing in Slavic languages
subsection.p: Most Slavic languages have split-NP and split-PP preposing. Fanselow and Ćavar (2002) propose an analysis for split-NP and split-PP preposing in Polish and Croatian; Franks and Progovac (1994) discuss split-PP preposing in Serbo-Croatian; Siewierska (1984) describes information-structural aspects of these two split preposings in Polish; and Sekerina (1997a, 1997b) takes into account information-structural and syntactic aspects of split preposing in Russian.

Two types of split preposing can be distinguished for Slavic: (i) a type that is similar to SNPT in German, in which fronting brings about an inverse scope relation between the two base-generated parts of an unsplit NP, and (ii) a pull-split preposing comparable to split-NP preposing in Modern Greek, in which the scope relation of the split parts are the same as in the unsplit constituent. The two types of split-NP preposing are illustrated in (94) and (95). Split-PP preposing (cf. (96)), can only be of the pull-split type in Croatian; the inverted type is not allowed: 43

(94)
Croatian:
[Knijge] mi je Marija [zanimljive ___ ] preporučila.
books me has Mary interesting
recommended
‘Mary has recommended interesting books to me.’

(95)
[Crveni] je Ivan [ ___ auto] kupio.
red has Ivan
car bought
‘Ivan has bought a red car.’

(96)
[Na veliko] se Ivan [ ___ drvo] popeo.
on big self Ivan
tree climbed
‘Ivan climbed on a big tree.’
Fanselow and Ćavar 2002: (5b), (14a), (22e))

According to standard assumptions, pull PP-splits cannot be submitted to a subphrasal movement analysis because the modifier of the NP cannot form a constituent with the determiner. Therefore, Franks and Progovac (1994) propose a RM-analysis for the split-PP preposing in (97). As a first step, the NP moves out of the PP and right-adjoins to IP. Subsequently, the remnant PP topicalizes into Spec, C: 44

(97)

One of the problems that this analysis faces is that the structure gained after the first movement operation never occurs at the surface in this language. For example, NPs can neither be topicalized, nor be scrambled out of PPs (cf. (98)):

(98)

(Fanselow and Ćavar 2002: 72)

Franks and Progovac suggest that the ill-formed examples in (98) stem from a violation of a scope-preservation principle that makes surface word order strive to reflect the scope relations in base-generated structure as much as possible.
These problems motivate Fanselow and Ćavar (2002) to extend their C&DD-analysis they propose for SNPT in German (cf. section 3.3) to split-NP and split-PP preposing in Croatian and Polish.

Sekerina (1997a, 1997b) observes that split-NP preposing and split-PP preposing in Polish and Russian have some striking similarities. Four grammatical properties identified for split preposing in Polish by Siewierska (1984), hold for split preposing in Russian, too: (i) split-PP and split-NP preposing tend to involve phrases containing a noun and just one adjective; (ii) in the majority of cases, phrases are split into two parts that end up at the edges of the clause; (iii) PPs can only be split if the prepositional object is modified and no part of the prepositional object precedes the preposition; (iv) there can be only one split per clause.

Also in Russian, split preposings go hand in hand with a contrastive reading for at least one split constituent. In the wake of Androutsopoulou (1998a, 1998b) (cf. section 7.1), Sekerina (1997a, 1997b) proposes a focus-driven movement analysis for split-NP Scrambling in Russian, too. Different possible outcomes of split-NP Scrambling in Russian together with their prosodic structures are shown in (99) and (100) (cf. also Mehlhorn (2001) for a detailed information-structural description of split-NP preposing in Russian):

(99)
Russian:
a. [Cernyj ] on ljubit [ ___ KOFE ].
black-acc
he-nom
likes
coffee-acc
‘It is coffee that he likes to take black.’
b. [CERNYJ] on ljubit [ ___ kofe].
‘He likes to take his coffee black.’

(100)
a. [Kofe] on ljubit [CERNYJ ___ ].
‘He likes to take his coffee black.’
b. [KOFE] on ljubit [cernyj ___ ].
‘It is coffee that he likes to take black.’
(Sekerina 1997a: 384)

In contrast to Polish, where both split parts are focused in the majority of cases, resulting in a double-focus construction (cf. Siewierska 1984), both split parts can be focused only rarely at the same time in Russian (cf. Sekerina 1997a: n. 9). In general, split-NP preposing in Russian is appropriate in more contexts than in Polish. A contrastive context is no absolute desideratum and initial opening utterances of the discourse with split constituents are quite common (cf. Sekerina 1997a, 1997b).

Sekerina (1997b) proposes a double-movement analysis for split preposing in Russian: an unsplit DP or PP first scrambles into the specifier position of a higher FocusP (above IP and below CP). As a second step, a subconstituent is extracted out of it and becomes right-adjoined to FocP. Sekerina adduces two putatative causes for the fact that split phrases in Russian and Polish tend to appear at the peripheral edges of the clause (a descriptive generalization that is named ‘Periphery-Constraint’). One pragmatic driving force for split-NP preposing is formed by the purpose of focus assignment to one of the two subparts of the discontinous constituent by moving it into FocP. Another information-structural force for split preposing is formed by deaccentuation as defined by the nuclear-stress rule as formulated in Cinque (1993) (see chapter 49).

subsection.heading: 7.3 Split topics ‘Chinese-style’
subsection.p: Chinese-style topics are typical of topic-prominent languages, such as Japanese, Chinese, and Korean (see chapter 73). One type of whole-to-part relation exploited by this topic construction is the kind–subkind relation. The most famous Japanese example stems from Kuno (1973c) and is represented in (101):

(101)
Japanese:
[Sakana -wa ] [tai -ga ] oisii.
fish topic
redsnapper nom
delicious is
‘Speaking of fish, red snapper is the most delicious one.’
(Kuno 1973: 62)

As opposed to SNPT with a full-NP rem in German, Chinese-style topics in Japanese are not island-sensitive, as shown in (102) for the Complex-NP Constraint and in (103) for the Coordinate Construction Constraint:
