Although it is almost unanimously agreed upon that the topic in these constructions does not bind an empty site, but is base-generated in situ, transformational analyses have been suggested, too (see chapter 73).

subsection.heading: 7.4 Miscellanea
subsection.p: A construction that seems to be somewhat reminiscent of the double-subject construction in (101) is the existential construction in Malagasy, a topic-prominent language (cf. Pearson 1996). Existential clauses in Malagasy are headed by the verb misy, which takes a small-clause complement. Existential clauses are used to introduce new referents or situations into the discourse.

Besides other ‘part-to-whole’ relations, misy can express a superset–subset relation between the outer subject (or ‘topic’ in Pearson's terms), located at the right-edge of the clause, and a predicate-internal argument:

(104)
Malagasy:
[PredP
Misy [maro ___ ao an-tokotany]] [ny raozy].
exist many
deic
loc-garden
det-def
rose
‘Of roses, there are many in the garden.’
(‘Many of the roses are in the garden.’)
(Pearson 1996: 115)

In (104), the topic ny raozy ‘roses’ denotes a set or a kind of which the NP maro ao an-tokotany ‘many in the garden’ forms a subset (or ‘subtype’) or instantiation. Pearson (1996) assumes that an abstract unaccusative light verb be takes a small-clause complement DomP, whose head (Dom0) takes a nominal complement and assigns a Domain (or ‘superset’ theta-role) to a DP that is base-generated in its specifier position, in order to establish the superset–subset relation between the predicate-internal and the predicate-external argument. Finally, it is argued that Dom0 raises and incorporates into be and that the result of this process is spelled out as misy.

A construction that seems only remotely to be similar to SVPT in German and Dutch is the so-called predicate cleft (P-cleft) construction occurring in many West African languages. An example is Vata, a language of the Kru family (cf. Koopman 1984, 2000b). P-clefts involve two overt copies of the finite verb: one in sentence-initial position and one in the regular clause-internal position. The preposed verb is focused and contrasts with some other verb in the discourse that may be implicit:

(105)
a. [Lē

‘We are (really) eating rice.’
b. [L imacr

‘S/he has eaten rice.’

s/he ate rice
‘S/he ate rice.’
(Koopman 1984: 38)

As shown by the examples in (105), the preposed focused verb is a segmental copy of the verb in clause-internal position. The fronted focused verb merely consists of the segmental specifications of the verb, i.e., without tonal specifications. Since elements with no associated tone surface with a mid tone, the focused verb invariably surfaces with a mid tone. The focused verb can be inherently marked for aspect, too, as in (105a). However, the imperfective aspect is the only kind of aspect that may appear on the focused verb. And tense morphology cannot appear on the focused copy either. So in a way, the clause-initial copy is bare. In principle, any verb that may serve as the input for a morphological process can be clefted, but auxiliaries and other semantically defective verbs cannot undergo P-cleft, as they do not have enough semantic content to be focused. Koopman (1984) demonstrates that the dependency between the two verbal copies created by P-cleft is an A-bar-dependency.

In Koopman (1984), it is argued that the focused verb is moved to a clause-initial position (i.e. C0) by head movement of the wh-type. It is argued that an overt copy of the fronted verb must be left behind, in order to prevent a violation of the ECP, since otherwise the clausal-internal verbal wh-trace is not properly governed.

Koopman (2000b) proposes a completely different analysis in which P-cleft involves remnant-XP movement. As a consequence, P-cleft is considered to be A-bar-movement of the usual kind, i.e., of an XP (and not of a head). Whereas in the head-movement analysis (cf. Koopman 1984), it is the spell-out of the clause-internal verbal copy that has to be explained, it is the spell-out of the copy in focus position that asks for an explanation in the RM-analysis. According to Koopman (2000b), the clefted verb must be overt because it is included within the fronted VP that cannot form a chain with the clause-internal verb, which is assumed to be in I0. 45 So, the spell-out of the focused verb is required by reasons of recoverability and by the fact that only overt copies can be focused.

An analysis of the P-cleft data in (105) in terms of the C&DD-analysis is tempting (cf. section 3.3), since this analysis conceives movement as a process consisting of two separate operations, whose noncomplementary effects could somehow surface in this verb-fronting construction. However, also under this movement analysis, many questions remain open, at least at first glance. For example, why does the ‘partial’ or ‘imperfect’ copy appear in sentential-initial position and not in clause-internal position? However, in the traditional movement analysis, in which movement leaves an empty category, the P-cleft construction gives rise to completely different questions. For example, why does this construction leave more or less an exact replica of the fronted verb instead of a resumptive pronoun as usual in a resumptive-pronoun strategy? See Koopman (1984: ch. 6) for discussion.

subsection.heading: 8 Conclusion: outlook
subsection.p: In sum, a problem for all syntactic analyses of SNPT is that they cannot offer a straightforward solution for the full range of different possible realizations of top and rem. As soon as analyses aim to take into account all the possibilities in different varieties, they either overgeneralize or have to appeal to ad hoc mechanisms. Since there exists a considerable amount of dialectal variation with respect to the possible syntactic realizations of top and rem, the possibility that SNPT is not a unitary phenomenon should not be lost sight of. Most analyses exclusively concentrate on SNPT, sometimes in combination with MST, but they have completely ignored split NPs in Split-NP Scrambling and in Split-CLD until now. Another issue that remains to be explored concerns the possible syntactic realizations of top in the alternative target positions of ST.

The analyses for SVPT also appear to be confronted with quite a different problem. Then, apart from the problem that is posed by movement paradoxes, both types of analysis face the problem of relating top to the free order of arguments within the extended, restructured VP in the predicating clause.

These investigations lead to the ultimate question of parameterization, i.e. the determination of the necessary conditions for SNPT (cf. also table 3) and SVPT to occur in a particular language. It has been suggested more than once in the past literature (cf., for example, den Besten and Webelhuth 1990) that the existence of ST correlates with the availability of Scrambling. But although both German and Dutch are Scrambling languages that allow for SVPT, not all varieties of these languages have SNPT as well.

Gouskova (2001) argues that split preposing results from the interaction of violable constraints with opposing demands. Her optimality-theoretic approach adopts a set of information-structural requirements that potentially conflicts with barrier constraints for different categorial types. Since these barrier constraints are ranked in a particular order, extraction from VP is predicted to be more likely than extraction from NP.

Fanselow (1988: 97ff.) observes two correlations for languages with discontinuous NPs, such as German, on the one hand, and non-configurational aboriginal Australian languages on the other hand: (i) if a language has discontinuous NPs, adjectives and determiners can also form NPs by themselves, i.e., the language has elliptic NPs; (ii) if a language allows for discontinuous NPs, it also has rich overt agreement morphology within NP.

In determining the relevant factors for the possibility of split NPs in a language, the possibility of NP ellipsis (see chapter 22) appears to be a relevant factor indeed (cf. also Van Hoof 1997b, forthcoming; Kuhn 1999; Mathieu and Sitaridou 2003; emphasizing this point). Also other languages with clause-internal split NPs, such as Latin, Finnish, Hungarian and West Greenlandic, allow for NP ellipsis, too. Furthermore, it has become clear from investigations in the more recent past (cf. Lobeck 1995); Kester 1996) that correlations (i) and (ii) are related too, since elided nominal catagories need agreement morphology on the overt nominal remnant to be licensed.

Also in non-configurational languages, the correlation between strong agreement morphology and the occurrence of split NPs appears to be valid. As shown by the example set in (106–107) originating from Nash (1986), NPs can only be split if each of the individual members is marked for case and agreement, although this is not required for the unsplit NP (cf. (106b)):

(106)
Warlpiri:
a. [Kurdu-ngku wita-ngku] ka maliki wajilipi-nyi.
child-erg
small-erg
aux
dog chase-agr
b. [Kurdu wita-gku ] ka maliki wajilipi-nyi.
child small-erg
aux
dog chase-agr
‘The small child chases the dog.’

(107)
a. [Kurdu-ngku] ka maliki wajilipi-nyi [wita-ngku].
child-erg
aux
dog chase-agr
small-erg
b. *[Kurdu] ka maliki wajilipi-nyi [wita-ngku].
child
aux
dog chase-agr
small-erg
‘The small child chases the dog.’
(Fanselow 1988: 96)

Furthermore, the similarity of discontinuous NPs and elliptic NPs does not only become apparent from the obligatory agreement morphology on the adjective licensing the gap in both types, but also from the specific semantic class of the adjective, which has to be a predicative one. Mathieu (2003) reaches this conclusion for split NPs and elliptic NPs in Romance, Van Hoof (forthcoming) independently with respect to German and Brabant Dutch, and Partee (2001) reports a similar result for split NPs in Polish.

On the other hand, it cannot be claimed that a language is parameterized to have split-NP preposing if this language allows for elliptic NPs. Then, although NP ellipsis is probably a necessary condition it cannot be a sufficient one. For example, Spanish and Swedish are languages with NP ellipsis (cf. Kester 1996), but they do not have split-NP preposing with connectivity effects.

Fanselow (1988) argued that discontinuous NPs in non-configurational languages do not differ from split NPs in configurational languages. In his view, the base-generated VP structure underlying SNPT in German, which contains two independent argument NPs with the same theta-role (cf. section 3.3), also suffices to account for discontinuous NPs in non-configurational languages. Van Geenhoven (1998) provides additional semantic support in favor of this view. She shows that N-incorporation structures in West Greenlandic that occur together with a VP-internal doubling argument (cf. (108)) can be unified with the base-generated structure for SNPT in German (cf. (109)):

(108)

‘Jensi will eat two eggs. / # Jensi will eat two of the eggs.’

(109)

‘As for eggs, Jensi ate two.’ (Van Geenhoven 1998: 44)

Van Geenhoven (1998) argues that both the incorporated noun in West Greenlandic and the to-be-fronted NP in German SNPT are property-denoting NPs that cannot gain wide scope because they are semantically incorporated into the verb (cf. Mathieu and Sitaridou (2003) for a similar explanation).

One more common property between SNPT and discontinuous NPs in (some) non-configurational languages deserves to be mentioned. Some incorporation languages allow an incorporated noun to appear together with an external full object NP, whereby the incorporated noun includes the reference of the external noun. Such an example is provided by Mithun (1984) for Mohawk:

(110)
Mohawk:
Sha'te:ku snikú:ti rabahbót wahu-tsy-ahní:nu ki rakeniha.
eight of them bullhead he-fish-bought thus my father
‘My father bought eight bullheads.’
Mithun 1984: 870)
Of course, examples like (110) are highly reminiscent of the occasional occurrence of full-NP rems in German.

Fanselow's (1988) hypothesis that discontinuous NPs in non-configurational languages do not differ from split NPs in configurational languages is countered by the ‘Pronominal Argument Hypothesis’, according to which overt NPs in non-configurational languages function as modifiers or adjuncts to VP instead of VP-internal arguments. Since non-configurational languages are often characterized by a rich case or agreement system, it has been hypothesized that in these languages, the agreement morphemes or clitics satisfy a predicate's argument slots. Therefore, the overt (split) NPs do not really count for the Projection Principle. Under this hypothesis, discontinuous NPs are expected to be of quite a different type than split NPs in configurational languages. For example, the number of discontinuous NPs in non-theta-marked positions modifying a particular argument slot are predicted to be unlimited. Split NPs in configurational languages appear to be stylistically marked, for they can only occur in certain contexts, although their exact information-structural interpretation varies from language to language, perhaps because split-NP preposing in these languages constitutes a marginal phenomenon. The question arises whether split NPs in non-configurational languages are information-structurally restricted, too. This and many other questions require further research.

subsection.p: However, in accordance with the extended-projection-based definition for ST adopted in section 1.2, it could be argued just as well that IP in (i) forms an extended verbal projection that is headed by the participle gegessen ‘eaten’ and that the topicalized phrase forms a split VP (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1998a: 12, n. 11, for a suggestion along these lines). However, here we only deal with the clear examples or SVPT, in which an extended verbal projection has been split in such a way that at least one argument of the split VP in top has been stranded in the clause. Note furthermore that, unlike for the examples of SNPT, no stylistically precise translations are rendered for the SVPT examples for complexity reasons.

p.span: 25 Still one other option is available, however. The VPT in (55) and the SVPT in (56) can be derived if the extraposition of a CP argument is obligatory, but not before PF. The same kind of movement paradox can also be constructed for SNPT (cf. Fanselow and Ćavar 2002: 97).

26 For a slightly different view on the status of grammaticality of sentences like (57b), see Grohmann (2000b) and Erb (2001). According to Grohmann (2000b: 189), sentences like (i) are grammatical in some varieties of colloquial German and Dutch:

row.entry: ‘My friends don't like to work very much, they'd rather go partying.’

p.span: 27 For example, in restructured VPs, the arguments of the different verbs are permutable, as shown by the contrast in (i), the verbs can undergo V-raising and operators can have scope over the entire complex VP (cf. Fanselow 1989; Meurers 1999); (chapter 75, this volume):

row.entry: ‘that no one has tried to read the book’
‘that no one has refused to read the book’

p.span: 28 (58b, c) have been borrowed from Müller (1998: 18). An anonymous reviewer points out that the SVPTs in (58b, c), as well as the SVPTs in (68), can also be derived from an underlying Third-Construction variant (cf. (i)), which is often analyzed in terms of ‘remnant extraposition’ (cf. Den Besten and Rutten 1989; Broekhuis et al. 1995):

row.entry: ‘that no one has refused to read the book’

subsection.p: However, see Müller (1998: 18, n. 17) for a reason why das Buch ‘the book’ cannot have been locally scrambled within the domain of the infinitive α in (ii), which is the underlying structure of (i):

p.span: 29 Note that the permutation of arguments within top and within rem, after SVPT has been completed, is allowed for, however (cf. Haider and Rosengren 1998: 8 for a similar observation):

30 However, no clear NTCC can be derived for the alternation between direct and indirect objects. In the restructured VP, whose main verb is hinterlassen (‘to bequeath’), the dative argument is ranked higher than the accusative object (cf. Thiersch (1985), Müller (1998) for the same observation):
31 According to Haider (1990b), the ungrammaticality in (64) vanishes if the direct object is represented by a weak pronoun or by a deaccented NP, as becomes apparent from (i):

row.entry: ‘An outsider has never won it/that yet.’

subsection.p: However, the status of the grammatical contrast between (64) and (i) is still rather unclear at this moment.

p.span: 32 However according to Müller, Scrambling of split VPs is sometimes possible, namely if the stranded argument in rem is represented by a weak pronoun or a clitic:

row.entry: ‘that no one has tried to read it’

subsection.p: Note that pronoun movement and cliticization in Germanic are generally not believed to be instances of Scrambling, but instances of a different movement type (see chapter 13).

p.span: 33 Still more analyses of SVPT can be distinguished, but they are mere suggestions that have not been worked out so far. Discussion of them will therefore be omitted. For example, Van Riemsdijk (1989a) considers extending his X-bar-movement analysis for SNPT to SVPT in German, but since there is no real evidence for relexicalization in top of German SVPT, which makes regeneration visible, this possibility has not been pursued. Weerman (1989) and Zwart (1993) suggested the LD-cum-operator analysis for SVPT in Dutch. Hinterhölzl (2002) argues that the C&DD-analysis (cf. section 3.3) is inappropriate for SVPT and provides an alternative analysis based on a strictly right-branching structure (cf. Kayne 1994) combined with RM-movement.
34 See Huang (1993) for another technical solution to the problem of unbound traces in top of SVPT.
35 Müller (1998) refers to SVPT by the name of Incomplete Category Fronting. Since this term also subsumes NP–PP Split, it does not equal the notion of ST used here.

36 Note that the neutral type of Scrambling that is triggered by the referentiality or definiteness property of arguments (see chapter 43) cannot be at stake in (71) and (72) because the stranded arguments are nonspecific indefinites. Hinterhölzl (2002), who assumes a VO-based restructuring account, introduces yet another type of clause-internal movement, called ‘licensing movement’, which can apply to all verbal dependents irrespective of their referential status. This type of movement precedes Scrambling and empties the to-be-topicalized VP in remnant T. It is assumed that this movement type does not create freezing effects.

37 In Haider and Rosengren (1998), this type of Scrambling is called Topic Scrambling and it is assumed to target a position directly below C0. The question of which term is more on the right track will not be answered here, and neither will the question of whether this Scrambling type can be equated with embedded Topicalization in English (see chapter 23).
38 Some speakers of Brabant Dutch also allow for the split variant with a d-pronoun in situ:

row.entry: ‘As for cows, he has quite a lot in the rearmost meadow.’

p.span: 39 Additionally, Split-NP Scrambling can also occur together with different types of Split-CLD in Brabant Dutch (cf. Van Hoof forthcoming).

40 Besides the pull-split type of split-NP preposing, Modern Greek also allows for the inverted (German) type of split NPs, as illustrated in (i), an example that originates from Horrocks and Stavrou (1987):
41 In (93), ‘e’ denotes a null-head modifier, i.e., an elided nominal head.
42 Mathieu and Sitaridou (2003) and Mathieu (2003) apply this analysis to a split-NP-preposing construction that is attested in some varieties of Romance, too:

subsection.p: In passing, Grewendorf (1995) also proposes an underlying small-clause structure for SNPT in German, in which rem forms the subject and top the predicate of a base-generated small clause in the middle-field (cf. Grewendorf 1995: 1299).

p.span: 43 The discussion of split preposing in Slavic languages sometimes also includes (pull-split wh-phrases (cf., for example, Fanselow and Ćavar 2002), a split type that is not considered here. As becomes apparent from the main text, Franks and Progovac (1994) provide examples from Serbo-Croation, while Fanselow and Ćavar (2002) offer examples from Croatian. Although Serbian and Croatian are very similar, they are still considered to be two different languages. The (artificial) language Serbo-Croatian was brought into existence for political reasons in the past. Probably, Serbo-Croatian examples are grammatical both in Serbian and in Croatian, but we stick to the language terminology employed by the authors here.
44 Note that Franks and Progovac (1994) base-generate NP as a complement of A0 (cf. Abney 1986). They also suggest the RM analysis as a viable alternative for pull-split-NP preposing.
45 Both Koopman (2000b) and Pearson (1996) adopt a strictly right-branching base structure (cf. Kayne 1994) and the constituent order at spell-out is derived by successive leftward movement.
